results.content: The downloaded code has references missing. Package folder is missing

response.content: Rashmi - you get the packages by using the Vis Studio "Restore NuGet packages..." menu option when right-clicking on the _solution_ at the top (not a project-- the whole solution item).  Same as with source control, you normally leave out any packages and let the build process download them as needed to avoid bulking up the file set.
response.content_html: Rashmi - you get the packages by using the Vis Studio "Restore NuGet packages..." menu option when right-clicking on the _solution_ at the top (not a project-- the whole solution item). Same as with source control, you normally leave out any packages and let the build process download them as needed to avoid bulking up the file set.

results.content: Good lectures. Only thing that is not right is the code;  I guess when this course was originally published may be git repository was small; but now if you follow the git hub link you will find so many commits and it is hard to find the code that is being referenced in the video. I would suggest to include the commit# as well when referencing the code on git hub.  The section on Parameter binding has this link: https://github.com/WebApiContrib and if you follow that you will find code since 2012!  Please take time to either add all code to the video or tag a link with commit#. Thanks.

results.content: At first, I found the instructor to be a little mono toned and not a very dynamic speaker. This can make it a little challenging to stay engaged. However, the content is certainly there, the syllabus is nicely organized, and the instructional level is perfect for me (not too basic and not too advanced, perfectly intermediate) . The instructor is more than sufficiently knowledgeable on the subject matter. So, now that I am deeper into the course, I can see and understand that my issues were more about giving myself the much needed kick in the rear to get going and put in the work learning this. Can't blame the instructor for that.

results.content:
I cannot speak highly enough of this course and the tutor, Darren. I started having never used Web API but the real-world examples given, coupled with Darren’s commentary on different ways of achieving a particular goal and the pros and cons associated, have given me a really solid understanding of the various components of the Web API pipeline and the confidence to go on and work on my own projects.

Darren is always quick to help whenever you have any questions, always providing a thorough response. It is clear he loves what he does and is very knowledgeable in this field. This is also the first course I have taken on Udemy whereby you can submit assignments and get feedback on them (others I have taken only feature the quizes). I feel these help further the understanding of the course material and were a really useful addition.

Top marks from me. Thanks for all your help Darren!
results.content_html:

Darren is always quick to help whenever you have any questions, always providing a thorough response. It is clear he loves what he does and is very knowledgeable in this field. This is also the first course I have taken on Udemy whereby you can submit assignments and get feedback on them (others I have taken only feature the quizes). I feel these help further the understanding of the course material and were a really useful addition.

Top marks from me. Thanks for all your help Darren!

results.content: This course is simply amazing. It is very technical and full of real world examples that help you see the bigger picture. The assignments are very useful. If you want an intro to Web API or a fancy hello world, look for other courses. If you are a software engineer and need to own your technological stack, look no further. This is a reference course.
results.content_html: This course is simply amazing. It is very technical and full of real world examples that help you see the bigger picture. The assignments are very useful. If you want an intro to Web API or a fancy hello world, look for other courses. If you are a software engineer and need to own your technological stack, look no further. This is a reference course.

results.content:
Darren has been an amazing resource to learn from throughout the duration of the course. I went into this course with next to no knowledge of Web API programming, and now feel ready to deliver a fully functioning system after only a week. He has quickly provided feedback on assessments and his answers to student questions have been fantastic, even answering things that are out of the scope of the course. 

The real strength of this course comes from the 'real world' approach. There are discussions on Load Balancers, per method permissions, etc. Each discussion comes with code that could be copied and pasted into a separate Web API project and integrate with existing features with ease. The assignments were the right mix of familiar principles as learned in the course, and building upon the functionality in useful ways.

This course does require a decent level of programming knowledge, but not necessarily in C#. Knowledge of classes, delegates and some overall good practice coding will really help in understanding the content.

I would love to see future courses from Darren. Buying this course on special feels a bit wrong now that I have seen the value he has provided; something with this level of detail and applicability would typically sell for a lot more through Microsoft or other certifying bodies.
results.content_html:
Darren has been an amazing resource to learn from throughout the duration of the course. I went into this course with next to no knowledge of Web API programming, and now feel ready to deliver a fully functioning system after only a week. He has quickly provided feedback on assessments and his answers to student questions have been fantastic, even answering things that are out of the scope of the course.

The real strength of this course comes from the 'real world' approach. There are discussions on Load Balancers, per method permissions, etc. Each discussion comes with code that could be copied and pasted into a separate Web API project and integrate with existing features with ease. The assignments were the right mix of familiar principles as learned in the course, and building upon the functionality in useful ways.

This course does require a decent level of programming knowledge, but not necessarily in C#. Knowledge of classes, delegates and some overall good practice coding will really help in understanding the content.

I would love to see future courses from Darren. Buying this course on special feels a bit wrong now that I have seen the value he has provided; something with this level of detail and applicability would typically sell for a lot more through Microsoft or other certifying bodies.

results.content:
This course is great! The content gets explained in depth and are tailored to real life applications. This course does a terrific job of explaining the different layers of Web API. 

The more than excellent theoretical content is supplemented with good exercises to practice what is learned and quizzes to test your knowledge.

Darren (teacher) is very involved in this course and will respond fast whenever someone asks a question and often gives very elaborated responses.

This course is great! The content gets explained in depth and are tailored to real life applications. This course does a terrific job of explaining the different layers of Web API.

The more than excellent theoretical content is supplemented with good exercises to practice what is learned and quizzes to test your knowledge.

Darren (teacher) is very involved in this course and will respond fast whenever someone asks a question and often gives very elaborated responses.

results.content:
I like the course very much, Instructor has touched all main topics thoroughly with really useful examples, This course will be a good start point for any developer who wants work on ASP.NET Web API.
Instructor has also covered the internal architecture of ASP.Net which helps to understand things better.

results.content: I'm currently trying to write WebAPI services in the new .Net Core 3 framework and this course (although written against an earlier version) has enabled me to get stuff working fine. The only problem has been with the authentication side of things but I am confident I will be able to crack even that problem. I have not had any web experience or entity framework experience and have only been programming WebAPi stuff for a big project at work for about a week now and it is starting to come together. So I think I have made exceptionally good progress, mostly due to this course. My background is as a traditional desktop and backend C# developer of over 17 years .Net experience.

results.content: Half-way through and content is perfect for me (IT Professional with MVC & C# knowledge).  I knew nothing of Web API, but feeling much more confident about using it.  It focuses on Web API and Web API alone, which is great.  That's all I wanted.  Don't be expecting any end to end examples encompassing business logic, database.  So far there are no examples of coded invocations of web API either, just examples of how to test from utilities like Swagger, Postman and Fiddler.

results.content:
There's a lot of really useful, great information in here, but be aware that the content is really for experienced C# users only. I really appreciate that the presenter focuses on the API framework and not language/code conventions here. He tells you how to use the framework and what he thinks is best, rather than extended examples.

In the video descriptions, he says that he wanted to make the course he wished he had before having to learn about API 2.0, and I think he succeeded. Each section has downloadable template code to write your own extensions that plug in to the pipeline. These are super useful and have lots of comments that will save you hours of reading through MSDN documentation.

So what's with my rating? Well, I think there's some things left to be desired here. First, the intro videos and descriptions sometimes go on tangents that are unncessary and long. The video quality is relatively poor, I think it maxed out at 720p. The text is still rather fuzzy at that resolution. The audio quality got distracting at times, with breathing and mouth movements being distracting at times.

Content-wise, this course is an A+. Presentation-wise, the cheesy graphics, unnecessary music, and lack of production value rate a solid C. That said, this course is well worth your money. It's like you got to sit down with a professional developer for an entire day of their hard-won experience. This is definitely a course I'll be referring back to over the next few years even as .NET Core's API rises in popularity.

response.content: Michael -- Udemy has recently enabled 1080p for the course videos so you should be able to get better than 720p now.  Just set the quality to "Auto" and it will upgrade if your connection supports it.
response.content_html: Michael -- Udemy has recently enabled 1080p for the course videos so you should be able to get better than 720p now. Just set the quality to "Auto" and it will upgrade if your connection supports it.

results.content: Most of the things are theoretical. less practical approach

response.content: Biswa, truly sorry you feel that way.  What I was trying to give you was tools to handle the kinds of complexities you see in the real world, with actual client callers, often doing cross-platform calls so there won't be a common library you can use, that other courses don't give you any tools to solve.  Other than the couple of things I specifically point out that I haven't (yet) needed myself, pretty much everything you saw came from actual experiences that really happened to me doing real commercial services in a large, global corporate environment.  Anyone can tell you how to return "Hello World" or "Add these two numbers and return the result".  What I wanted you to see was how you authenticate, authorize, deal with the load balancer your Ops team mandated, establish an agreed framework for communicating errors to each other, etc.  In other words, how to deal with all the things an actual working developer trying to solve the kinds of integration problems you will run into building commercial services, when none of the other courses and web sites who don't give you the advanced tools are of any help.  I assure you, the tools I gave you here are quite practical and not at all theoretical-- I've actually used them myself.  I hope some seed I planted here will help you later when you run into one of those integration scenarios yourself.
